SEARCH
Package org.loudouncodes.combinatorics

Class Combinations

java.lang.Object
org.loudouncodes.combinatorics.Combinations
public final class Combinations extends Object
Utilities for enumerating k-subsets (combinations) of the ground set {0,1,...,n-1}.

Overview

This class exposes a fluent builder for two common models:

  • Without repetition (default): Each element may appear at most once in a combination. Enumeration order is lexicographic.
  • With repetition (multiset combinations): Elements may repeat. We represent each multiset as a nondecreasing int[] of length k. Enumeration order is lexicographic over those arrays.

Additionally, for the non-repetition model you may request Gray order (also known as revolving-door order) via choose(k) → Combinations.KChoose.inGrayOrder(). In Gray order, successive combinations differ by exchanging exactly one element (symmetric difference size 2), which is useful for certain incremental algorithms.

Fluent usage


 // No repetition (default), lexicographic:
 for (int[] a : Combinations.of(5).choose(3)) {
   // ...
 }

 // With repetition (multiset combinations), lexicographic:
 for (int[] a : Combinations.of(3).withRepetition().choose(2)) {
   // yields [0,0],[0,1],[0,2],[1,1],[1,2],[2,2]
 }

 // No repetition, Gray (revolving-door) order:
 for (int[] a : Combinations.of(5).choose(3).inGrayOrder()) {
   // consecutive tuples differ by swapping exactly one element
 }

Contracts & guarantees

  • All iterables return fresh defensive copies on each next().
  • Iterators obey the standard contract: after exhaustion, hasNext() is false and next() throws NoSuchElementException.
  • Time per emitted combination is O(k); memory is O(k).
  • Counting methods are available via Combinations.KChoose.size() (best-effort long) and Combinations.KChoose.sizeExact() (exact BigInteger).

Pedagogical notes

  • Lexicographic order for combinations without repetition starts at [0,1,2,...,k-1] and advances by the standard “rightmost bump” rule.
  • Lexicographic order for combinations with repetition starts at [0,0,...,0] and advances by increasing the rightmost entry that can still grow.
  • Gray (revolving-door) order is produced lazily by a stack-based traversal of the classic recursive decomposition: G(n,k) = G(n-1,k) followed by reverse(G(n-1,k-1)) with (n-1) added.
